question: Should animal testing for medical research be allowed?

content.source_1: National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIH) — “Why Are Animals Used in Research?” (fact sheet). Summarizes how animal studies enabled major medical advances (e.g., insulin for diabetes, vaccines, organ transplantation techniques) and argues that, because of genetic and physiological similarities, whole-animal systems remain necessary for understanding complex biology that cannot yet be replicated in vitro.
content.source_2: Muñoz-Fontela, C. et al. (2020). “Animal models for COVID-19.” Nature 586: 509–515. Reviews hamster, ferret, and nonhuman primate models for SARS-CoV-2, concluding that animal studies were crucial for elucidating pathogenesis and for preclinical evaluation of vaccines and therapeutics—evidence that in certain infectious-disease contexts, animal models are indispensable.
content.source_3: National Research Council (2011). Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals, 8th ed. National Academies Press. Lays out legally recognized oversight (IACUCs) and the 3Rs (Replacement, Reduction, Refinement), requiring justification of animal use, minimization of numbers, and refinement to reduce pain—supporting the view that, when allowed, animal research can be ethically constrained and regulated.
content.source_4: Hay, M., Thomas, D.W., Craighead, J.L., Economides, C., Rosenthal, J. (2014). “Clinical development success rates for investigational drugs.” Nature Biotechnology 32: 40–51. Finds that only about 10% of drugs entering human trials succeed, despite extensive animal testing—evidence often cited to argue that animal models poorly predict human outcomes and that reliance on them should be curtailed.
content.source_5: U.S. Congress (2022). Food and Drug Omnibus Reform Act, Sec. 3209 (“FDA Modernization Act 2.0”). Amends federal law to allow nonclinical tests for drug approvals to include validated non-animal methods (e.g., cell-based assays, organs-on-chips, in silico models), signaling regulatory acceptance of alternatives and challenging the necessity of allowing animal testing in many cases.
content.source_6: The Cambridge Declaration on Consciousness (2012), University of Cambridge. States that a range of nonhuman animals (including mammals, birds, and octopuses) possess the neurological substrates for conscious experience, bolstering ethical arguments against subjecting sentient animals to invasive research and supporting calls to prohibit or radically limit animal testing.
